newsitem.title: POLAND: GROWING DOMESTIC CONSUMPTION FUELS POLISH GROWTH.
newsitem.headline: GROWING DOMESTIC CONSUMPTION FUELS POLISH GROWTH.

text.p: Rising real wages in Poland are spurring domestic consumption which has replaced exports growth as the main engine of economic expansion, the Central Statistical Office (GUS) said on Thursday.

"Increasing demand of households...has become one of the major factors, if not the major factor, as far the creation of economic growth is concerned," GUS deputy president Janusz Witkowski told a news conference.
According to GUS, real wages increased 5.2 percent in the first half of this year, compared with the same period of 1995.
Retail sales were nine percent higher in the January-July period than in the first seven months last year.
"What is important is that the growing dynamics of sales concern mainly non-food products, which shows that the economic condition of households is improving," Witkowski said.
In the January-June period of 1995, imports growth was not significantly bigger than the rise in exports and both exceeded 30 percent, with the trade deficit amounting to $473 million.
In the first six months of 1996, exports increased only 6.4 percent and imports 30 percent, generating a trade gap of $3.1 billion.
According to the government's Central Planning Office, gross domestic product should grow by about six percent this year.
